Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: ABI Development: A Modular, Community Based Design Platform for Synthetic Biology (Clotho)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Synthetic biology attempts to design novel biological systems to address a number of challenges in bioenergy, biotherapeutics, and bioremediation. However, synthetic biology is facing two very fundamental challenges: data management and standardization. This project will complete the development of the Clotho software platform for synthetic biology. Clotho is an environment which links repositories of biological data (databases) to modular, user created 'Apps' through a common interface which reflects a data model specifically tailed to synthetic biology. Apps then can be used together to create specific design flows ranging from high level specification of biological functionality all the way down to basic sample tracking and laboratory management. The project will strive to (1) create the first standardized data model for synthetic biology captured as a software platform. (2) To create a complete application programming interface to access this data model via software 'Apps'. (3) To create a global community of users via a website designed from the ground up to create, share, and collaborate around software development. (4) To create a polished initial software distribution including appropriate user interfaces and applications to address the immediate needs of synthetic biology labs.

The broader significance of this project is to establish a design framework for the automation and standardization of software in synthetic biology. Educational opportunities include Clotho development in the International Genetically Engineered Machine (iGEM) competition. Design automation coursework will use Clotho at UC Berkeley and Boston University. The App store (clothoapps.org) will serve as a portal not only for Clotho development but also as a community resource. Discussions regarding software tool development and use, documentation of ongoing research projects, and storage and retrieval of code and software libraries will be enabled by this effort. Finally, the International Workshop on Bio-Design Automation (IWBDA) will host Clotho developer and user meetings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Clotho data model has undergone development to cover a wider variety of use cases for software tools in synthetic biology. This has included the revision of existing Clotho schemas or data templates, the creation of new schemas for representing data previously outside the Clotho data model, and the modularization of the code responsible for performing create, read, update, and destroy (CRUD) operations on data adhering to these schemas.

The attached image is a Unified Modeling Language (UML) diagram that depicts the Clotho data model. Each schema in the data model has been colored to indicate the layer of biological or experimental design to which it belongs.

For the purpose of biological design, the green structural schemas are used to specify biological sequences and describe how these sequences can abstracted as parts for assembly in accordance with a format. In addition, green schemas are included for the molecular representation of sequences as linear or circular polynucleotides inside a particular strain. The blue functional schemas are used to organize the features that annotate each sequence into functional modules and assert feature-to-feature influences, such as repression and activation. Finally, the cyan class, Biodesign, is used to compose parts, polynucleotides, modules, and strains into designs that that include data on environmental context required for proper design function (orange schemas) and quantitative measures of design efficacy or other system parameters (magenta schemas).

For the purpose of experimental design, the red schemas are used to specify experiments for analyzing biological designs under different experimental conditions. In the case of a factorial design, its factors and levels and the experimental conditions implied thereof can be associated with biological designs that contain different combinations of parts, thereby enabling experimentation over a combinatorial design space. The magenta schemas are used to indicate the parameters and variables of an experimental design and record sample data. Finally, the yellow schemas are used to capture the physical implementation of biological designs and experiments in the lab as samples that are separated into containers and plates and measured using different instruments.

With the addition of the security layer, Clotho server development is largely feature complete. Development focus has transitioned to supporting Clotho's use in 'real life' scenarios, as a data warehouse for other applications & an authoring platform for synthetic biology app authors. Recruitment and support of a community of users and developers has begun.

Clotho's functionality has matured to the point that it can now be utilized as a database management tool for other Synbio CAD tools. Libraries (plug-in APIs) have been created for Clotho such that apps and tools written in Java or Javascript can easily store and process data via Clotho. These plug-ins provide a link to Clotho and facilitate the integration of new features into Clotho's existing database management features. Also, numerous, demo applications and CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) apps have been created to provide the community with easy-to-use sandbox web-applications to help them get started with their Clotho 3.0 app or Clotho-based Software tool.
